ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
N/A
Lots of discussions in the class along with mini lectures as we went over the topics we were learning about.
n/a

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to deeply analyze literature and understand arguments authors are making regarding sports. My essay writing and structure was also improved through this courses two papers.
While this is not a writing course, I improved my writing skills and also widened my scope of sports and the significance they have for different people.
I learned how to better analyze pieces of sports writing. I learned how to incorporate aspects of everyday life into sports writing.
Learned about different styles of literature and how to write clearer.

I learned about how authors and journalists write about sports and the ways athletes are portrayed by them. Most of the skills that I developed had to do with close reading and looking at specific passages.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Creswell (great speaker, easy to listen to, carries/continues conversation well), workload (2 projects and 2 papers)
Weaknesses: sometimes readings (books) were a crunch with other classes workload too
The strengths of this course are the readings and the discussions; they were all worthwhile and interesting.
This class would be very fun in person, but I thought we did a pretty good job executing our discussions through zoom.
Strengths: Very engaging and the discussions were both informative and interesting
Great course selection for the books.

A strength was the consistent reading work and how there was a variety in the pieces that we read. A weakness was that we didn't get much support with the writing assignments or get much feedback on our writing apart from feedback from assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Breakout rooms and live lecture were great, kept me attentive.
Dont really have any suggestions for the virtual system put in place. Can only do so much.
This course was great for learning during the COVID-19, and the readings, films, and guest speakers helped make this course interesting.
I thought the class did a very well adjusting to virtual learning. I do not think there is anything that could be done differently.

Breakout rooms could have been utilized more but the professor did a fair job at making classes engaging. There could have been more opportunities outside of class to be involved in the class. Check-ins with him throughout the semester were helpful!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you love sports even a tiny bit, then this course will be a fun one for you. Remember though it is focused on the LITERATURE of sports, so you will be doing mostly readings and analyzing them as well.

Yes! I would recommend this course to any student who's interested in learning about a variety of sports from around the world. The readings in this course are all interesting and the discussions were always compelling as well.

If you're interested in sports wiring and sports literature I would definitely recommend this course. We went over lots of different writings from different sports which was very helpful for someone who is interested in sports writing.
yes.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in sports! It was so interesting to read about the world of sports and discuss in each class. We got to meet sports journalists and authors which made it even more cool!
